message.content:
There are 12 basic verb tenses in English, each indicating a different time frame or aspect of an action. Here they are:

1. Simple Present: Used for actions that happen regularly, habits, or general truths. Example: "I eat breakfast every morning."
2. Present Continuous: Describes an ongoing action at the moment of speaking. Example: "I am walking to work."
3. Simple Past: Describes a completed action in the past. Example: "She cooked dinner last night."
4. Past Continuous: Used for actions that started and stopped at the same time as the speaking. Example: "He was watching TV when I called him."
5. Present Perfect: Talks about an action's completion up to now, regardless of its time frame. Example: "I have just eaten breakfast."
6. Past Perfect: Describes an action completed before another past action. Example: "She had finished her homework before the party started."
7. Future Simple: Describes a future action that is general or expected. Example: "I will go to the store."
8. Future Continuous: Predicts an ongoing action in the future. Example: "They will be studying when I arrive."
9. Future Perfect: Describes an action completed by the time of a specific point in the future. Example: "By this time tomorrow, she will have finished her project."
10. Present Perfect Continuous: Talks about a continuous action that started in the past and continues to now. Example: "I have been learning Spanish for a year."
11. Future Perfect Continuous: Predicts an ongoing action that will continue up to a specific point in the future. Example: "She will be continuously working on her project for the next month."
12. Conditional Tenses (Present, Past, and Future): Used to express hypothetical situations or consequences. They have three forms each.

Note that some verb tenses can have subcategories like perfect aspect (完成体) and continuous aspect (进行时), which provide additional details about an action's duration.
